review.title: Underwhelming
review.review: Purchasing this laptops is another testament to the fact that good specs don't always amount to a great product. I was deciding between the Gigabyte 17" and a MacBook Pro 16" and finally picked the AERO because of it's impressive screen and graphics card. Needles to say I'm experiencing buyers remorse.The Bad:Horrible webcam/nosecam: I don't know why Gigabyte decided to even include this monstrosity. It's completely useless as it gives everyone in your Zoom meeting a detailed look up your nostrils. The cam is mounted in the body so it's not adjustable unless you raise the entire laptop. In the world of remote work a good, usable webcam is a MUST. Dishing out 2500 bucks and realizing that you still need to by an additional webcam to mount on your screen is a joke. GIGABYTE PLEASE FIX.Charging port: It’s located on the right, middle of the laptop which interferes with your mouse, if you have a tight space and are right-handed. Most coffee shops I go to have tiny tables and given the size of this 17.3” laptop there’s very little room.Battery life: I’m a graphic designer that works in 3D occasionally. When I use Photoshop/Illustrator and Dimension I can’t get more than 1 hour of battery life out of this thing even in power saver mode.Screen changes brightness: Yes, it will go darker or lighter without you touching any settings. Not the end of the world, but annoying.Screen goes black: I’ve used this laptop for a month and so far I’ve had at least 5 instances where the screen goes completely black for a second or two. Gigabyte WTF?Annoying keyboard: I’m used to Macs where to change volume you hit F11 or F12. In this thing you have to hold down the Function key in order to adjust volume, so it becomes a two handed operation. I find this really annoying as volume setting is something that is the most adjusted function and needs to be as intuitive as possible.RGB keyboard: This is a Creator’s laptop not a “gamer” laptop. Having the keyboard pulse like a rainbow on acid is not only distracting but also extremely tasteless. If you want to compete with Macbooks please get rid of this gimmick that appeals to 12 year olds.Now the Good:This thing is fast.The screen is beautiful.The GPU kicks ass. It’s 10 times (10!) faster at rendering 3D than my 13” Macbook pro.It’s relatively slim and not too cheesy looking (minus the RGB keyboard) which fortunately you can turn off.About $2500 cheaper than a similarly spec’d out Mac. Mac’s however have better ergonomics.Ports. Useful, but because of its shortcomings I have to use up one USB port for an external cam and another for a mouse. So it’s a mixed bag.Summary:This laptop is good if you keep it plugged in all the time and use it like a desktop. Hauling it around and working on the go is not a real option as you only have about an hour. Gigabyte needs to put more into their product usability testing.

review.title: Looks great and stays cool.
review.review: Over all a very solid machine. It's not perfect, but it runs great, looks good doing it, and won't burn you.2021 09 30 Update at the bottom.The Pros:*Very powerful CPU/GPU*Outstanding cooling system. So far the Aero 15 is running at least 20C cooler than my previous machine. Stock temps in the mid 40s, mid-high 70s under heavy load. I'd be surprised if I ever see this machine thermal throttling in anything remotely like a normal use case. Unlike my previous machine that would regularly hit 95C gaming. (see update about fan quality below)*The best looking screen I have ever seen on a laptop. Every other screen I have looks bland and washed out compared to this glorious 4k OLED. Pictures and reviews I've seen just don't convey how amazing it really looks.*Very good build quality overall.*Bright LED keyboard with a full numpad (fully customizable). Feels better than most laptop keyboards too.*2 RAM and SSD slots are easily accessible by removing the bottom plate (just one set of screws). Also got a thermal pad for a second SSD included in the box.*Built in sliding webcam cover. No need for tape on this one.*So. Many. Ports.The Cons:*The OLED screen is 60 hz. 4k 60 fps is great for most gaming scenarios, but I'd avoid this laptop if you absolutely need ultra high framerates, or want to play twitchy competitive shooters like CS or Valorant where more frames literally win games. The upside is that you can up the GFX settings more than on a higher refresh screen and still get the most out of it.*The OLED screen is not anti glare. There may be a technical reason for that, but regardless, avoid using this in bright areas, or while wearing any reflective clothing. It's reflective enough to be a decent mirror when turned off.*16GB of RAM isn't enough for a machine this powerful. Mine came stock with 2x8GB 3200 Crucial branded chips. They seem to be good RAM, just not big enough. It runs much better with 32GB 3200 HyperX installed. Can support up to 64, so there's room to improve when prices come down.*The built in webcam sucks, to be blunt. It's fairly low quality and poorly positioned. If you need a good webcam, hook up an external, there's more than enough ports to go around.*Gigabyte's Control Center software is a clunky mess, although it does have some useful features. Still not a fun experience using it though.*Unable to undervolt the CPU. This is more about newer chips than this laptop in particular, but I haven't found a way to do it safely.*The screen hinges are a bit weird. It's not loose or flimsy, but the screen can wobble a bit more than what I'd expect.*The function keys are horribly designed. The secondary function of each key is not illuminated, making it very hard to see in the dark. Sleep and Wifi are right next to screen brightness controls, and brightness up is on f4. I'm sure somebody has ruined their day by hitting the wrong button trying to change brightness. The fn key for keyboard brightness is the spacebar, and only has off, 'bright' and 'super bright' settings. For anything in between you need to use the software.*Built in speakers are mediocre. They're not too bad, but like the webcam, they feel like a cut corner compared to the higher quality of the rest of this system.Edit: A few observations after 3 months of use:* Gigabyte really cut corners on the fans. The cooling system works as well as I initially thought it did, but the fans themselves are low quality and wear out quickly. My GPU fan is already starting to wear out and produce irritating excess noise. There's no actual performance loss from it so far, but I've ordered a replacement fan.Dropped a star from 5 to 4 because of this, since after a bit of research it's been a persistent problem with the Aero series for years and remains unfixed by Gigabyte. This is the last place you want to use cheap parts. Inexcusably bad on a product that does so many things right.* I disassembled the Aero 15 for the first time to oil the GPU fan while I wait for the replacement, and I absolutely love the interior design. It's so well thought out and easy to tear down to clean or repair. The heatsink has numbered retained screws, and there are fewer screws than I'm used to seeing in general. Also no easy to break ribbon cables in sight. The downside, again with the fans, is that you have to remove the entire heatsink to access them, so I had to repaste as well.*Oiling the GPU fan reduced the noise it was making by about 80%. This isn't a long term fix, but it does treat the symptoms. Note that this is NOT something the typical end user should be attempting to do. If you aren't confident about your ability to open up a laptop this could be a much bigger problem that requires an RMA, and from what I've heard Gigabyte RMA is a horrible experience.*Also worth mentioning since I tried it, this laptop does not run well with Linux on bare metal. Maybe somebody more experienced with Linux could get it running good, but I couldn't. Stick to VMs or WSL if you need Linux on this machine.

review.review: The screen is terrific, and the form factor is light enough, esp. for a gaming rig.Two things that I didn't notice from the product pictures that are super-annoying:1) The power connector is on the right *middle* of the unit -- since the adapter has an anti-static bulge about 1-1/2" from the connector, you will have to put up with this unsightly cylinder of black plastic as you work whenever this laptop is plugged in. (You can't access the ports on the right if the power cable is facing frontwards.)2) The RGB per-key lighting is beautiful BUT the secondary characters (i.e., when you hit Shift) like for the lighting, sound and even common characters like ( ) @ # $ % on the number row do not light up -- they are not backlit! The problem (via Reddit) is that the Omron switches -- which have excellent tactile feel and travel -- have center lighting only. All right, but the printed secondary characters are done in a wispy light gray which you absolutely cannot see in the dark. (This is a poor design choice here.) They should be near white -- or at least reflect the light of the keys a bit. I just couldn't use this as a developer at night -- you'll need a separate light on to write / program at night. Of course, if you are a good typist, it doesn't matter for the common characters, but for the lighting, sound and other functions you aren't likely to know them by 'muscle memory.')Otherwise, an excellent laptop, but these are two hands-on gotchas you might not notice till you try this out this system in real life.

review.title: Great laptop, but some weird software
review.review: I got this laptop for work and to play games while I travel, and it's awesome! It looks and feels like a professional's machine, not a gamer's toy, so it fits into any kind of working environment. Aluminum chassis, sleek black design, no excessive RGB lighting.It has a lot of useful ports and little need for dongles. The two USB-Cs were a nice touch. One of them will fast-charge my cellphone, which is a huge plus for me when on the go.The POWER of this machine is awesome. Even though its light and small, it can run VR games at full FPS, supports raytracing, and can run Unity, Slack, Visual Studio, 24 VNC clients and compile video at the same time. Can't believe this thing's got an i9 AND an RTX 2070 for under $2k. Be wary though: when this thing gets going, it gets HOT. You can't do real work / gaming on your lap, and I nearly burned myself touching the underside when I needed to move it.I haven't really tested the battery that well, but I did manage to do some off-and-on video editing / web browsing for about 4-5 hours before needing to charge. But as you should know, that kind of battery life is not going to last for long.The only problems I've had, other than its hot-to-the-touch underside, is the pre-installed software. As a tech pro, I'm okay with handling some of the hiccups, but others might have problems. First, the "A.I." it has installed is handy at times, an annoyance at others. You can read about it elsewhere, but my two cents: It's really cool how it handles power regulation for different apps so you don't have to. I was also pleasantly surprised when it changed my keyboard lighting based on what game I was playing, all automatically. However, the program is a bit CPU intensive, and it will override settings that you don't want it to touch, so you'll have to configure it accordingly; however, I usually just turn it off 100% to avoid fiddling with settings and to get some CPU utilization back.Most of the pre-installed software is just no use to me at all, and usually just cause annoyances. These can be easily uninstalled, but if you like a crystal clean machine upon purchase so you don't have to do anything (which doesn't really exist for current PC's anyway), you're gonna have a bad time.Also the camera is bad, but pretty on-par as far as laptop PC cameras go. I never use it, so it's fine for me.BOTTOM LINE: if you're thinking about getting a Razor Blade or an Alienware m15, seriously consider getting this. It has power, professional looks, and a small form factor for under $2,000.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 15, 2020
review.title: Terrible Fan Issues and Customer Support
review.review: Bought this laptop to use for college and games, and was extremely happy at first. After about 3 months of normal use, the GPU fan starting making an awful grinding sound. After getting to school, the fan eventually stopped working completely, causing the laptop to overheat and crash when doing things as simple as web browsing. Communicating with Gigabyte took 3 or more days between responses, and ended with having to pay $100 in shipping due to the warranty being limited, not full. It took nearly a two weeks (aside from shipping times) for a simple fan replacement that would likely take a technician no longer than an hour. During this time I had to work out getting a temporary laptop to use for school, which was an ordeal in and of itself.After receiving the laptop for the second time, it worked perfectly and I was once again happy. It is now 1 year later, and the other fan just died. The warranty only lasts a year, so it's up by now. I could easily do the replacement myself, but Gigabyte is stingy with their parts and I can only find a replacement fan from a third party for $85, which is far higher than the actual value of the part. After lots of research last year and this year, this seems to be a relatively common problem with the Aero 15 series in general. Despite loving the laptop when it works, this experience has prompted me to never want to buy a product from Gigabyte again.Don't be optimistic, don't be fooled by the generally good specs, don't take a risk, and don't waste your money; a laptop of this price should absolutely not have problems as simple as these, with such poor customer support to back it up. Despite the fact that there are some favorable reviews, if you would rather not deal with these same issues, go with a more reputable manufacturer.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on May 21, 2020
review.title: Rough edges overwhelm an intriguing idea
review.review: When I was looking to purchase a new laptop in early-mid 2019, my desired features were for it to be relatively thin and light while still holding a discrete graphics card, have a Thunderbolt 3 port (or more), and ideally have a monitor with good color reproduction.My intended use was primarily for gaming, but I was also looking for a portable workstation for photo and video editing.Unfortunately, most Windows laptops don't have Thunderbolt, end of.Of the few that did, most had only one, and often it was only available on models with lower-end processors and/or no discrete graphics card.And even the tiny number that checked those boxes generally had TN panels with limited color accuracy.So my selection was fairly limited.The AERO 15 seemed to have (most) of the specs I was looking for.And the new line had OLED displays that promised superb color accuracy.While the price was certainly higher, it had the best combination of size, weight, processor/GPU, and monitor available.Plus it had two M.2 slots for PCIe SSDs (another rarity), and seemed to be user upgradeable with relative ease, which was important given that the models available paired memory and SSD upgrades with faster processors and GPUs.Sadly, reality is much harsher.The problems started immediately.I had read that the AERO series could be finicky about the RAM it took.So after extensive research and finding lists of apparently compatible RAM on various forums (absolutely no official statement from Gigabyte, only supposedly official lists of compatible RAM provided by tech support and posted on forums), I selected a set that seemed to offer the best price/performance ratio for the range in which I was looking, and ordered it at the same time.After booting the laptop up the first time to confirm it worked, I powered it off, flipped it over, and began the laborious process of removing all 12 screws from the backplate.It took a bit of work with a spudger, but the backplate came off to reveal a fairly good arrangement of internals.It was a bit disconcerting to find that the thermal pad on the SSD had been folded in application and was mostly just scrunched up between the end of the SSD and the backplate.But nevertheless, it was easy enough to pop out the stock DIMM and replace it with my new paired set.Screwing everything back together, I plugged in the power, hit the power key, and...nothing.The laptop would not post.So out with the screws again (that was dumb), off with the backplate, double check that everything is seated properly, and nothing.One more attempt for good measure, and I decide to swap back to the original DIMM to make sure everything should work.Yup, no problem.So I spent several hours over that night and the next day trying to get my RAM replacement to work.I had a partial success fairly early on, when I got it to post with the original stick (8 GB Samsung) and and one of the new ones (16GB Corsair).Of course, it was then running both DIMMs at the slower speed of the Samsung, and there was no reason I should run a mismatched pair.So I pulled the Samsung and put in the other Corsair, and was right back to the black screen of futility.Eventually, I gave up.Some of that was forced, because I'm pretty sure I fried the Samsung DIMM by accidentally hotplugging it.How was it an accident?Well I forgot another fun feature of this laptop.It won't shut off.See it refused to post with the Corsair memory, but it still powered up, spun the fans, all that jazz.And when it didn't post, I'd hold down the power button to force it to shut down, and it would.And then, sometime in the next few seconds, it would start up again.And I was impatient, and wanted my relatively expensive laptop to work, so I didn't disconnect or discharge the battery, and I wasn't quite fast enough in swapping DIMMs before it powered on again.So I discharged the battery overnight, tried again the next day in every combination I could think of, and gave up and ordered a pair of the same model of Samsung memory it had come with.When the memory arrived, I inserted it, flipped the laptop over, hit the power button, and it was fine.Actually I think it made my heart sink by not posting the first time, but at the second attempt, it booted fine and I've never had an issue with not booting due to RAM since.Which brings me to the experience of using it.It's...fine.Gigabyte packages it with several control panels that are supposed to make customizing everything and getting the most out of it a breeze.From other reviews I read, this is a bit hit or miss, and it mostly just got in my way when I didn't actually want to make changes.It is a nice package - mostly black, no gaudy trim with the exception of the faux-chrome "AERO" plate between the rear heatsinks, and while it does have a giant AERO logo in LEDs on the lid, at least they're white.I had/have no complaints about the speed, though I haven't really pushed it.The fans are loud when they rev up, which is most of the time, though that's partly due to my leaving it on a fairly aggressive cooling setting.Crapware is mostly nonexistant (except for the unavoidable Windows stuff).But it's not just the firmware that has quality problems.The hardware also apparently has iffy quality control, as I've discovered today when my GPU fan bearings failed.Even if Gigabyte would still honor the warranty (if it even still falls in the warranty period), their RMA process is infamously bad, with every forum discussing issues with Gigabyte full of posts about a complete lack of communication from customer support.So where do I go from here?Would I recommend this version, or a newer one, or would I buy a Gigabyte laptop again?I'm not sure.When it was working, I quite liked it.But, purely anecdotally, every other laptop I've owned has just worked.I didn't have the stress of wondering if I had just sunk thousands of dollars into a fancy paperweight with other brands, just because my memory wasn't on a super secret list of four models (not even just brands; specific models) that would work.While they've worn out and/or gotten slower, that was after three or four years of hard use, not one.And I have no confidence that, if there had been a serious problem during the warranty period and I had wanted to return or get it fixed, that I would have had any success doing so.So I guess the tl;dr is:If you do plenty of research about the specific model you're looking to buy to find out exactly what parts you can use to upgrade it, and if you're willing to fly solo and/or with the help of random (helpful and kind) people on the internet, and if you're ok gambling that you won't have any major part fail quickly (but not so quickly it can be warrantied), then yeah, go ahead and get this (or a similar) laptop from Gigabyte.But if not, then I'd say it's worth whatever tradeoff there may be in increased price (potentially Razer) or slightly worse specs (Dell, several other brands) is probably worth it to avoid a brand and line that has so many issues.

review.title: Manual Adjustments Needed!
review.review: I had a Surface Book 2 before this one, but this OLED screen is probably the most beautiful laptop screen I've ever seen. Performance is good, but there's one MASSIVE CATCH.THERMALS were terrible, sitting around 52 *C on IDLE and upwards of 90 *C under load. Fans were ALWAYS running and very loud.I was about to return this until I tried to manually adjust a few things as a last effort (through Windows Apps only, I did not touch any hardware stuff since that may impact the Warranty/Return Policy). I have this laptop for only a few days, so take this with a grain of salt. I'll try to update if something comes up.First, you need to finish all of your Windows Updates.Then download Gigabyte Control Center from Gigabyte website if you don't have it already. Update every driver available through there. Then here's the tricky part. Refer to online threads (aka Google search) if you are not familiar.1) Go to Nvidia Control Center. Under Manage 3D Setting, change Power Management Mode to Adaptive.2) Open an app called Intel Extreme Tuning Utility (should be installed along with Windows Update, but download if you need to). Undervolt CPU Core and CPU Cache by 100 mV (-0.100 V). Decrease Graphics Ratio Limit by 2 units.3) Go to Control Panel > Hardware and Sound > Battery Options > Change plan settings (recommend do this for all options) > Change advanced power settings > Processor power management > minimum processor rate. Change all values to 0 or 1 %.4) Restart your PC.5) Go to Gigabyte Control Center again. Using the lowest CPU slider option and on Quite Mode in Device Setting, the laptop should run ~40-45 *C on idle, and fans should not be running when using typical web browsing/Office apps.When under load (playing games, video editing, etc.) changes above should not have noticeable effects on performance. It's a pity that the laptop doesn't come with these settings automatically, but this is the work you have to do if your unit has problems like mine. If these changes does not work, considering returning your laptop. Again, I only have this laptop for a few days. Take these advises with a grain of salt.

review.title: Not for casuals. Seriously.
review.review: If I weren't technically inclined I would be utterly heartbroken over this purchase. If all you do is edit photos and tinker around on the internet - it's fine but this laptop is marketed to power users. If you game in any capacity, do a lot of video rendering or anything that comes close to maxing cpu loads then you will absolutely thermal throttle 100% of the time. This laptop requires use of Throttlestop and the know-how to set it up. You cannot use intel XTU. After setting it to max out at 3.8-3.9 Ghz and setting a -150mv undervolt it now barely ever breaks mid 70 degrees Celsius. Before it would it 90 degree before a games splash screen was loaded. It was that bad. 4.0ghz seems to be the tipping point before heat skyrockets.Next, a few weeks ago the gpu fan started making crunching sounds and then go silent. I opened the monitoring utility and saw that when it went silent that it was actually turning off. The fan was trying to start and puttering out. I had to disassemble everything to get to the fans and take it apart to oil it after 2 months of ownership! The entire inside was spotless but it seems that bad fans are pretty common and other people have had to send their computers away. NOPE! Not this guy. Cost me 7 bucks because I had to repaste the CPU and GPU over a freaking bad fan - thank god the motor still had power. I just thought the cute little guy liked to chirp at me from time to time. Didn't know it was a time bomb.Next, RAM. Just buy Samsung. Don't do anything else. Other motherboards will let you mix brands - hell even frequencies. This one is a picky eater.So with that being said, where else are you going to get a laptop this BEAUTIFUL and UNIQUE? This product once the bugs are sorted is an absolute joy. The GPU now easily overclocks 100mhz (MSI Afterburner) and runs neck in neck with the desktop version with (now) great thermals and frames. I can now take it anywhere without worrying about it self-destructing.However, the fact that if I were a common consumer I probably would be without a computer and living in warranty nightmare I cannot recommend this to anyone aside from techy nerds. If at any point you did not understand my jargon - back off. If you did and are not intimidated - enter at your own risk and use my experience to guide you.
